purpose_overview.goal: Maximize muscle hypertrophy and training performance by emphasizing carbohydrate intake
purpose_overview.approach: Moderate-to-high caloric surplus (10–20%) with high carbohydrate intake (5–7 g/kg/day or higher)
best_for: Athletes performing high-volume resistance training or multiple daily sessions
Individuals with fast metabolisms or high carb tolerance
scientific_basis: High carbohydrate availability optimizes glycogen stores
Supports higher training volume and intensity

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Estimate TDEE using Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation
caloric_strategy.surplus: Add 10–20% (~300–600 kcal/day) and adjust weekly based on weight trends

macronutrient_breakdown.carbohydrates: 5–7 g/kg/day (up to 8–10 g/kg for extreme training)

rationale.protein: Sufficient for maximal protein synthesis (Morton et al., 2018)
rationale.carbohydrates: Fuels glycogen replenishment and performance (Burke et al., 2017)
rationale.fats: Lower fat percentage allows more carbs while maintaining hormonal health

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: 20–40 g per meal spaced every 3–5 hr

pre_workout.2_3_hours_before: Moderate-to-high carbs (e.g., pasta or rice), lean protein, and low fat
pre_workout.30_60_min_before: Optional simple carbs for a quick energy boost

meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: Within 2 hr: 20–40 g protein + 1–1.5 g/kg carbs
meal_timing_distribution.hydration: 40–50 ml water/kg/day; include electrolytes for heavy sweat sessions

supplements_optional.name: Creatine Monohydrate
supplements_optional.evidence: Proven to enhance strength and power

supplements_optional.name: Whey or Plant Protein
supplements_optional.evidence: Convenient protein source to meet intake

supplements_optional.name: Carb Powders
supplements_optional.note: Useful for intra- or post-workout carb boosts

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Track weekly averages; increase carbs by 5–10% if weight gain stalls
monitoring_adjustments.training_performance: Monitor fatigue; ensure carbs are sufficient pre- and post-workout
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Check every 4–6 weeks to monitor fat gain and adjust accordingly

advantages: Maximizes glycogen storage for higher training intensity and volume
Provides quick energy and reduces perceived exertion
Ideal for hard gainers or athletes with high caloric needs
limitations: May not suit individuals prone to fat gain or insulin resistance
Requires fiber and food volume management to avoid GI discomfort
Can be challenging for those with lower appetites
references: Morton RW et al. (2018). Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376-384.
Burke LM et al. (2017). J Appl Physiol, 122(4):1025-1038.
Kerksick CM et al. (2017). J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 14:33.
American College of Sports Medicine (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
